contentrichtext.text: {{unicode|'''Ɀ'''}} (lowercase: {{unicode|'''ɀ'''}}) is a Latin letter [[z]] with a "swash tail" (encoded by [[Unicode]], at codepoints U+2C7F for uppercase and U+0240 for lowercase) was used as a [[phonetic transcription|phonetic symbol]] by linguists studying [[African languages]] to represent a [[voiced labio-alveolar fricative]] ({{IPAblink|ʷ|zʷ}}).<ref>[http://std.dkuug.dk/jtc1/sc2/WG2/docs/n2799.pdf Proposal to add two Africanist phonetic characters to the UCS], Michael Everson & Peter Constable, June 12, 2004.</ref><ref>[http://std.dkuug.dk/JTC1/SC2/wg2/docs/n3447.pdf Proposal to encode two phonetic characters and two Shona characters], Lorna A. Priest, October 2, 2007.</ref> In 1931, it was adopted into the [[orthography]] of [[Shona language|Shona]] for a 'whistled' ''z'', but it was dropped in 1955 due to the lack of the character on [[typewriter]]s and [[typeface|font]]s. Today the [[digraph (orthography)|digraph]] [[zv (digraph)|zv]] is used. == Notes and references == <references/> ==See also== *{{unicode|[[ȿ]]}} *{{unicode|[[ƍ]]}} *[[Ȥ]] "Z with hook" {{Latin alphabet|Z|}} [[Category:Uncommon Latin letters|Z]] [[Category:Phonetic transcription symbols|Z]] {{Latin-alphabet-stub}} {{writingsystem-stub}}
